Sure, here's an example of a short melody in Turkish style that can be represented in the text format described above:
```
8
C 4
D 4
E 4
F 4
G 8
F 4
E 4
D 4
```
This file specifies that there are 8 notes in total. Each line represents one note, with the letter of the note (C, D, E, F or G) followed by the duration (in ticks) to hold that note.

This melody starts with a sequence of descending notes C, D, E, F and then followed by a G note which is held for 8 ticks, and then again the sequence of descending notes F, E and D.

Please note that this is just a simple example, in real use cases you will have many notes and durations, and you might need to adjust the program accordingly.
Also, in Turkish music notes are used differently than western classical music, in addition to that there are many different scales, modes, and ornamentations. This example melody is just a simple representation of a melody in Turkish style, but it would not be a typical representation of a real Turkish melody.
